title: Will automation lead to loss of jobs? - Quora

response.answer_text: In a strict sense, without a doubt, automation will lead to loss of jobs. However, it is fruitless to debate how many jobs will be lost by automation vs. how many will be created. For instance, to argue over how many jobs the invention and implementation of the Internet created or destroyed is pointless. Nobody can do anything but speculate on strict numbers. The real issue is what kind of jobs are created in the wake of the job loss due to automation, and also what the secondary effects of the job loss are. One example to explore these concepts is the production of burgers in retail restaurants and fast food places. There are a couple million people employed in the U.S. making hamburgers in food establishments. Right now there is a machine being tested that supposedly can make a few hundred burgers per hour at the same quality or even better than the burgers made by people. If these machines are implemented on a mass scale and everyone making burgers by hand is put out of work, it is interesting to think about the effects of that. There would indeed be jobs created by the fact that the burger machines must be manufactured and distributed to the retail food establishments. But what kind of jobs are those? There is probably going to be a small team of engineers to design the machines, another team of people to manufacture the machines and then yet another team to distribute the machines and operate/maintain them. Then, of course, there are managers to oversee the business activities. The total number of people employed in these capacities is probably going to be a lot less than a couple million. And not only that but the education requirements for these workers is going to be a lot higher. It appears that automation raises the bar in terms of educational requirements for participation in the workplace. Sure, automation creates jobs as well, but in theory those jobs are going to have steeper requirements in order to operate the machines and software that have been implemented. There are secondary effects as well, though, and those are probably a lot more difficult to quantify. In theory, the lower cost of the burgers produced by the machines will free up resources in the economy. If I can buy a burger for $1 instead of $6, that's $5 I can spend elsewhere. Will those freed up resources end up creating other jobs for the people who were once employed making burgers? One possibility is I decide I can spend that $5 on better food and I stop eating burgers. Then, those who lost their jobs might be employed making better food. But then, once again, it is more likely than not that those jobs will require more education.

Yes, for sure. There will be massive job loss. But not yet. Machines can do a lot, but they can’t do everything we can do. We don’t have AI CEOs and entrepreneurs yet. This gap is what keeps us employed. As jobs are lost, we just find something else for the workers to do. But this gap is closing fast. Within a few decades, the gap will close. The machines will have general intelligence beyond our own. Our machines will be able to do everything a human can do, and then it only becomes a matter of cost. Once machines have the general intelligence of humans, no job will be safe from automation, and there won’t be anything a human can do that a custom-designed AI couldn’t do better. A custom smart AI can work 24 hours a day. No need to sleep or deal with other issues. So even if it's expensive it will replace at least 3 humans that only work about 8 hours a day. AIs can save their memory and reload from a different saved file. So if an AI trains for 10 years to learn a new skill and knowledge, its memory and personality can by cloned into 100,000 copies of its hardware with a simple download. We can’t do that with humans. We have to send each one of them to school to learn the same lessons. So it’s not just the fact that a machine has the same intelligence we have, it will have powers like memory sharing that humans can’t that will make them far more valuable in the economy. We don’t have the technology yet. But once we have general AI it will still take decades for the new technology to evolve and be implemented and for our industries to transform. Just as we are now in the 3rd decade of the public internet, and we are still seeing business models transforming to take advantage of the internet, the social transformations created by the rise of the internet are still unfolding. The transformation of the workforce due to the rise of general AI will take many decades after we have the technology to make it happen. No one knows for sure when we will have the needed technology, but most/many people working in the field believe we are very close. Every year new records are broken on getting machines to do things they couldn’t do before. And there is now the massive investment in this technology because everyone knows we are close. There is a huge gold rush about to unfold. Today, it’s a gold rush mostly in research. But soon, it will be a gold rush of deployment. By the end of this century, our economy will be a vending machine, not a place for human employment. There will be no way for your average person to make a living in a job. There will be ways for humans to sell their time, such as people that become famous will still be able to sell their time just so people can meet them. Whether it’s because they are a sports star or a political star, or YouTube celebrity. If you become famous at something, you will still be able to cash in on your fame. But only a very small number of people will get that option. There will be jobs that pay people for their time, but think of them as volunteer work. The jobs people want to do, like maybe take care of dogs at a dog shelter, teach kids. They will be what we choose to do because we enjoy it, and many may be totally voluntary, but many may also offer some pay. But none will pay enough to live on. In this new feature, we will have to learn to share the output of the machine economy, not expect people to contribute to it with their labor, our labor will nearly worthless. The money will all go to the people who OWN the machines—the capitalists. Whereas today’s economy is about 60% labor and 40% capital rents, once machines become smarter than humans, the labor share of the economy will drop like a rock, for the first time in history. By the end of the century, it might 10% labor and 90% capital. Those that own the capital, will receive that 90% of all economic output if we don’t learn to share that capital wealth. We will share the capital wealth with a Basic Income system. Everyone just gets cash every month. They get to spend in our big automated vending machine economy. We can, and should, already be sharing a large share of our economy's capital wealth with a Basic Income. If we shared half of the capital wealth, that would be 20% of the entire economy, which in the US works out to be a Basic Income of about $1000 a month for everyone. We should be doing that now as a way to share the capital wealth which then also gets us ready for this fast-approaching day when the labor share will drop like a rock. But if people don’t understand or believe this will happen then we will just wait until the labor share drops like a rock, and then they will understand and scream for their share of the lost wages as a Basic Income.

I disagree with this whole statement of "automation => loss of jobs". If it was the case than globalization would be also implying loss of jobs, ... We know it is not the case for these. They definitely drastically changed what jobs are available in a given country but the number of jobs did not really decrease. As an illustration one can look at this graph from Wikipedia about US Labor participation for 1948 to 2011 (Unemployment in the United States (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unemployment_in_the_United_States#mediaviewer/File:US_Labor_Participation_Rate_1948-2011_by_gender.svg)):  As you can see despite having the globalization of the economy during this period the overall trend (black line is both male and female) is relatively flat if not trending upward. Sure less american works on factory now than it was in the 50's, and of course some people did lose their job as their enterprise relocates in cheaper country; but globally the US job market did rebalance itself and the same thing did happen in most countries. You see indeed that in the US (from the same Wikipedia article again) unemployment rate is related to level of education and this just amplified as we went to these evolutions:  But yet as I said earlier these job crisis tend to regulate themselves after the society have time to adapt to the deficit of jobs in a given sector: should this deficit been generate by cheaper human labor or automation reducing the need for humans.  It is actually a problem that has been studied by economists and opinion is divided (see the section about is the same wikipedia page Unemployment in the United States). All agree though that automatic both create and destroy jobs they just disagree on which is the strongest and if it will continue one way or another.  On my end, I tend to trust the self-regulatory nature of your economic systems. I am not necessarily fully agreeing with this system but cannot deny its ability to adapt using the simple principle of offer vs demand. Reducing cost using automation -- or relocalisation or any other mean -- is good for the enterprise as it reduce its costs and potentially increase its profits. But again this would work this way only if they are able to maintain the same demand for the same demanding price. If they weaken the demand by suppressing all the jobs and nobody is here to compensate this loss they come then to a problem: their product may be very cheap to produce but nobody can afford it even at this cheap price. Hence the need of a balancing act surprising jobs altogether makes automation meaningless as nobody will buy what you produce. It works only if on, average, the global population with buying power still remains relatively constant. There is definitely people that will be left out as "irrelevant" due to automation of certain tasks/jobs but eventually there has to be either new type of jobs emerging to compensate for this deficit or a slow down of automation so enterprises can maintain a profit.  And this balancing is true since the early ages and I do not see it challenged any time soon.

Some of the evidence they cite includes the many other times in history where people feared machines would create unemployment. They did change the job landscape, but they didn’t create widespread unemployment. However, just because it didn’t happen in the past doesn’t mean it can never happen. Some claim we’ll absolutely have technological unemployment — that machines and software will eventually do so much of the work that we won’t have enough jobs for people. Their debate is not about if this will happen, but when. Some of this argument is tied up in the debate about AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) and when it will occur. Even before AGI, we seem at most two decades away from widespread automated driving cars — which will displace substantial workforce. Will there be enough jobs created to employ these people in other ways? We don’t know yet. Perhaps more fruitful than debating whether or when this will happen or not (hint: nobody knows) is to look at the problems our society will experience if technological unemployment does happen. For one, the US tax system will need to be substantially reformed. Currently a bulk of taxes are collected as payroll income taxes. As machines take human jobs, corporate profits go up, but net taxes collected go down. If technological unemployment does happen, this will create a decrease in net tax revenue at the same time that there is a strain on social programs to support the growing unemployed workforce. Expect to see “the new new deal” to rebalance the tax system around this new reality. Technology also exaggerates wealth disparity. Those who own businesses growing more profitable because of technological unemployment grow richer, while those losing their jobs grow poorer. In some cases standard of living goes up, but because intelligent machines are expensive to develop and produce, most of their net benefit goes to their inventors and the rich, not the poor. Another interesting topic is which jobs are safest from technological unemployment. The answer is, jobs with “messy” interfaces and/or requiring higher intelligence. It’s possible to make an automated factory, or even an automated driving car, because the interface between the computer and the world is very structured. An automated driver merely needs to control the gas, brake, and steering wheel. Further, roads are very structured, and can be methodically mapped and navigated with GPS. It is substantially more difficult to automate folding arbitrary home laundry than to automate driving. Laundry comes in too many forms, and takes too much dexterity to manipulate to be automated soon. The same is true of higher intelligence. The creation of entertainment, software, contracts, law, and other forms of complex intellectual property will be some of the last things to be handled by machines. In fact we will need to reach Artificial General Intelligence for these things to be automated, and at that point everything will be so much different it’s not clear what our problems will be.

Yes, automation leads to loss of jobs. That’s the main purpose of automation. Automation is expensive, if it didn’t make more money than it costs, they wouldn’t do it. For example, we’ve seen that in manufacturing employment since 1980 and especially since the turn of the 21st century.  Note that despite the loss of more than 1/3 of manufacturing jobs, production kept up it’s steady upwards trajectory. So much for the idea that even if machines replace workers, increases in production will necessarily maintain employment. What happens, instead, is that the reduced cost of production, combined with competition, drives down prices, and lower prices gradually lead to greater sales to those who haven’t lost their jobs. And that greater demand for greater production means more workers are needed, so employment rises again. And that’s what we’ve always seen: massive job losses over time followed by massive job creation. This chart shows the employment rate of 25–54 year old Americans since WWII.  Of course, female employment was fairly low in the early post-war years, but rose steadily over the following 40 or 50 years, so we need to interpret this chart carefully. In fact, if we consider only male employment, to exclude this effect, we see a very different picture (the orange line below).  Male employment declined 15% from its peak around 1950 to its trough in 2010, and was still 10% below that peak before the Covid-19 collapse. But the interesting thing to note in both of those charts is the trend toward increasingly erratic swings in employment: with each crash, more jobs are lost and it takes longer for them to be regained. What if the problem here is that the jobs that are lost are less skilled, and the jobs that are introduced require more skill? This would be leaving behind workers who are unable to attain the skills needed for the “jobs of the future”, leaving more and more workers behind. And that seems to be what’s happening: labor force participation of less educated prime-age men has declined more than 13% since 1964, while participation of more educated men has fallen much less.  (This is labor force participation, which counts both those in jobs and those looking for jobs, so the fall reflects both those who don’t want to work and those who have given up looking for work.) To date, most of the jobs that have been eliminated by automation have been simple, repetitive jobs, but we need to consider what will happen as AI technology starts displacing larger numbers of more skilled workers, such as Robot Radiologists, Artificial Intelligence Will Revolutionize eDiscovery, and AI Is Impacting Journalism. Consider this: what happens when AI comes to dominate shipping, delivering cargo using self-driving trucks? The cost of shipping products falls, making online shopping cheaper. That displaces a lot of retail workers, while increasing online demand, which is more heavily automated and requires fewer workers. Then we may see talking machines taking call centre jobs; again it’s unclear how those jobs would be replaced by new employment made possible by increased productivity. But before closing I must make one more point: we’re focusing on the wrong problem. Everyone talks about how we must make more jobs, but it’s not jobs we need. What we need is production and income with which to buy that production. We’re assuming the only way to achieve that is through employment, but If we have robots and AI giving us the production we want without the need for human labor, then all we still need is income. So let’s not fixate on jobs; if we don’t need labor to produce what we want, there won’t be jobs. Rather than trying to create make-work and Bullshit Jobs to underpin employment, let’s recognize that the problem is not lack of jobs, it’s the need for a new mechanism to distribute all that production that no longer needs human labor.

Every time I have looked into this question the answer has been that increases in automation actually increase employment rather than reducing it. The new machines can only do limited things but they can do it in  high volume and all day long.  They never need breaks and they don't get sick or need vacations.  So long as the work to be done can be completely defined in a simple enough way that a machine can do it the machines will do it better and for less cost than low skilled people.  Some examples of jobs machines can do very well include picking up parts from one place and putting them somewhere else (such as for printed circuit board assembly); spray painting automobiles and parts; simple assembly tasks such as putting nuts on bolts and tightening them; reading codes on grocery packages and collecting payment for purchases. The machines require attention from time to time.  Operators need to get involved when complicated problems arise.  One example would be a case where an automatic checkout machine in a grocery store doesn't acknowledge money that was deposited in the machine.  Machines are very bad at communicating with customers and a skilled human is needed to deal with many of the problems which can arise. Machines also need programming and repair.  These jobs require specialized skills to perform.  While an unskilled person can be trained quickly to be a checkout clerk in a grocery store or a teller in a bank it takes many months or even years for a person to learn how to program the machines that do these tasks and at least months for a person to learn how to repair a machine when it stops working. The bottom line is increased automation means many unskilled workers will be replaced by the machines but many more people will be needed to perform the higher skilled tasks that arise because the machines are being used.  Without additional training the low skilled workers replaced will simply become unemployed.  Those who can and do learn how to do the more difficult jobs will earn more money and enjoy higher demand which means continued employment and competition between employers to hire them.

Whether automation will destroy jobs on a massive scale is still an open question. Itamar Ben Hamo recently explored the idea in his recent article: How Automation Is Impacting Jobs During the Pandemic. As Ben Hamo outlines, the debate at hand focuses on whether automation creates, changes, or kills jobs -- and there are plenty of competing opinions. According to Sami Atiya, president of Robotics & Motion, automated technology will create many more jobs than it destroys. MIT's Erik Brynjolfsson and others hold that automation will change the jobs we already have. On the other hand, some, including former U.S. Presidential candidate Andrew Yang, claim that automation harms workers and eliminates jobs. Of course, this was the automation debate before the pandemic just a few months ago. Since then, apocalyptic predictions about mass job loss have intensified. However, this isn’t borne out in the data we have so far. Automation has increased during the pandemic - but only at a modest rate. Automated floor cleaner company Brain Corp says it has seen a 13.8 percent robotic usage increase in the first quarter of this year among retailers in U.S. locations and a 24 percent rise in the second quarter. With offices closed, PayPal has used automated chatbots for a record 65 percent of all customer inquiries. So there’s a mismatch between the rhetoric and the reality. Studies say millions of job are “exposed” to automation, but exposure is not the same thing as definitive loss. At the same time, automation is indeed increasing, though not at apocalyptic levels. So where does the answer lay? Likely somewhere in the middle.

No. Not only does automation not have a long term impact on employment rates, it’s actually the only way to grow the economy.  The Logic Behind Automation & Employment Let’s look at the logic at the bare bones level: All things being equal: Automation (more productivity) means fewer jobs. This is because it allows fewer workers to make the same amount of stuff.For example, if you add some robot welders to a factory, you may only need half as many human welders as you did before.More output (making more stuff) means more jobs. This is pretty obvious: if you decide to make 10% more cars, you’ll need 10% more workers.Therefore, if automation (economic efficiency) increases at the same rate as output (economic growth), there will be no net gain or loss of jobs. Does History Support This Logic? In by book Bobbins, Not Gold I talk about how even in the 1100’s AD Europe was already beginning to automate. For example, textile weavers in Flanders invented elaborate machinery to full and weave cloth—this didn’t cause Flanders to have a bunch of unemployed weavers. It made them Europe’s industrial heartland, and most wealthy, and highly urbanized region. The same thing happened in the aftermath of the Black Death, which struck Europe in the 1350’s (depending upon where you were). Lots of people died, which meant that people needed to get creative if they were to continue building their civilization. During this time Europe underwent the “First Industrial Revolution” (as I, and other Medievalists refer to it), which saw the widespread adoption of paddle-powered engines (river mills) to automatically grind grain, full cloth, and chop wood. This, of course, culminated with the Renaissance. There are countless examples of similar situations, including the Industrial Revolution in Great Britain during the 19th century (or perhaps more properly, the Third Industrial Revolution), where technology grew rapidly, but did not cause systemic unemployment. The common thread of economic history is that better technology, vis-a-vis automation, has invariably made the West more prosperous. You can read more about automation and job loss here.

Yes. The open-ended question is how will we manage which jobs are lost and which are created? Industry selects automation projects based on the profit potential. Academic researchers cast a broader net and explore more topics like AI and androids. Some people are beginning to think about the social and political consequences of widespread automation. If automation continues to expand in the rather haphazard way that industry selects projects, I think the social disruption is likely to be greater than is necessary. I also suspect the transition period will be far longer and more painful than it need be. One possible solution is to focus our efforts on single industries and automate the entire supply chain from raw materials to finished goods. The program will require solving a large number of problems, probably many thousands. The good news is that we already have the necessary technology to automate all the tasks. Automated manufacturing does not use human-like robots, or androids. Instead, it applies specialized robots optimized for each task. For an entire supply chain, we would need thousands of such robots to perform all the tasks needed to acquire raw materials, process and refine them, fabricate parts, and then assemble the finished products. Again, this is doable with existing technology. All that is lacking is the will and motivation to tackle the larger job. Once an industry has been fully automated, the lessons from that project can be leveraged to automate the next industry in less time. Focusing on one industry creates space to consider the consequences of eliminating most human jobs from that industry. We could use that space to retrain workers. Many of those workers could help with the automation project by advising engineers on the details of each task. Politicians would have time to ponder and debate ways to deal with the loss of jobs. In my opinion, as a civilization, we need to take control of this transition. We know the end result: few or no jobs will remain that require human labor. Until AI develops something equivalent to human judgement, some people will still be needed to supply that vital aspect of decision-making, but the number will be small. We will achieve the best social results if we make this transition as short as possible, to minimize the misery and pain of widespread job loss.

It is difficult to conclusively know whether automation will increase unemployment, as shown in the diagram below. Depending on which study you read, the answer can be different.  Regardless of the results, the key point to note is that jobs will be transformed by automation, which may or may not lead to unemployment. The level of employment will depend on many factors. There are five factors according to McKinsey that will determine whether tasks or activities within jobs can be automated: Technically feasibility for doing so.The cost to automate the task and whether it makes economic sense to do so.Availability of skills and the cost of workers who might otherwise have to do the activity.Benefits (e.g., superior performance) and value of automation beyond just labor-cost substitution.Whether automation is permitted by regulation and is socially (and morally and ethically) acceptable to do so in the geographical location in question.

No. In the last hundred years many jobs were automated and disappeared but it did not affect unemployment rate: United States Unemployment Rate. No. Never. Economics and greed, not technology and automation, kill jobs. Technology makes many jobs easier to do, raising the opportunity cost of leisure by increasing productivity per hour. Technology can also, though, give us a completely new way of getting something done that’s much more cost-effective than the old way. The suits paying the salaries and signing the subcontracts decide that they can make bigger profits by moving to this completely new way of getting something done. They then kill the jobs associated with the old way, by no longer funding it.

Yes, it will result in a net loss. The primary driver of automation is reducing employee costs. Support roles for this new automation will be fewer than pre-automation. Ancillary job creation, I.e. Automation suppliers'  engineers and manufacturing personnel, will not be likely to fill the employment hole left by reducing the number of workers. One significant problem is the (apparent) conflict between the micro and macro view. We may worry, as a society, about dwindling consumer demand due to automation. But the business person, focused on his/her product sees the trees, not the forest. Their small contribution to efficiency in their business ends up undermining the economic system as a whole, and they may not be prepared for the systemic effects.

The Fourth Industrial Revolution is upon us. When advanced technologies like AI, robotics, and the IoT bring an end to work, the repercussions are simply mind-boggling. From surgeons to long-haul truck drivers, accountants to engineers, fast-food workers to writers, nearly any repeatable, predictable job is at risk. We usually think about manual labour as the field that’s most ripe for machine replacement, but in truth, high-skill jobs are easy picking, too. Estimates vary, but middle-of-the-road assessments think no less than 33 per cent of jobs will have fallen to machines by as early as 2025. Find out more at How do we find meaning, purpose, and identity after robots take our jobs? - Richard van Hooijdonk Blog

The last time I was answering a question, on how possible it was for people with no college qualification to get a job and the subject of automation came up, after that question on automation I've kept a keen attention in that and I've come across a lot of changes and redeployments going on due to automation. It will be a lot like going from horses to cars. Lots of job losses, stables, carriages, saddles, bridles, pasturing horses, manure cleanup, pony express, etc. all cut way back, over years. See my answer to your question  {Sandra Buskey's answer to Will there be jobs for people without college in the future?}

Everything I have read on future studies for the last 20 years points inevitably to automation replacing humans in a very, very wide spectrum of jobs. This is further reinforced by the progress of current events. Automation is replacing humans, and the pace of change is accelerating.  This leads to a much bigger issue, which Bob Smith has alluded to. Namely, what economic, social and political system will supplant what we have now. However jobs that involve many tasks like say cleaning of making up hotel rooms, then automation would be too costly. There’s little doubt that automation has, and will, lead to the loss of jobs. Is our future a nightmare as a result? If you want to read a prescient story about this kind of dystopic future, take a look at Kurt Vonnegut's Player Piano. Written decades ago, the kernel of the idea for the book came from his experience working at General Electric, which was beginning to automate. Are we doomed to live in Vonnegut’s vision? Or, are there things humans can do better than computers? In Humans Are Underrated, Geoff Colvin makes a strong case that there are things humans can do better. Here, I’ll quote from the book: “[O]ur greatest advantage lies in what we humans are most powerfully driven to do for and with one another, arising from our deepest, most essentially human abilities—empathy, creativity, social sensitivity, storytelling, humor, building relationships, and expressing ourselves with greater power than logic can ever achieve.” These “high-value skills” are trainable, Colvin argues. We shouldn’t strive to be better at what computers do; rather, we should strive to be the best at our most human qualities and characteristics.

Will automation lead to loss of jobs? Automation will eliminate the need for some jobs, but will almost certainly create a need for different jobs. As an example, with the invention of the printing press and its subsequent sophistication all the way up to modern printers, there is no longer a market for type setters or people to hand pull prints of books, documents, etc. But automated printing has facilitated an explosive expansion of existing markets and the creation of new ones, so while we have very few typesetters, we have many other professions born of automatic printing. This cycle of automation destroying old jobs while creating new ones could (supposedly) continue into infinity with humans being able to work in progressively higher realms of thought and function.
